title: VideoGrain: Modulating Space-Time Attention for Multi-Grained Video Editing
author: Xiangpeng Yang (University of Technology Sydney), Linchao Zhu (Zhejiang University), Hehe Fan (Zhejiang University), Yi Yang (Zhejiang University), ...
relevance_why: This work addresses multi-grained editing, which can inspire techniques for manipulating sound or music data in a controlled manner, applicable to Haohe's audio generation tasks.
background: The paper explores multi-grained video editing which involves editing at class, instance, and part levels based on textual descriptions.
contribution: VideoGrain introduces Spatial-Temporal Layout-Guided Attention to solve the challenge of semantic misalignment and feature coupling in video editing, achieving state-of-the-art results.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods often struggle with feature mixing and fail to maintain instance-specific attributes.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by modulating both cross-attention and self-attention mechanisms to achieve fine-grained control and separation of features across instances.

key_innovation: Utilizes novel attention modulation to ensure that local edits focus precisely on intended regions while avoiding interference between different features.
real_world_impact: This advanced technique can enhance video editing applications, providing tools for filmmakers and content creators to achieve greater control over the editing process.

new_terms.Spatial-Temporal Layout-Guided Attention: **Spatial-Temporal Layout-Guided Attention** refers to a mechanism that adjusts how attention is distributed among various regions in a video, allowing for precise control over which parts are edited based on textual prompts.
new_terms.text-to-region control: **Text-to-region control** involves using text prompts to dictate modifications to specific areas or objects within a video, rather than applying uniform edits.

open_sourcing: Code, data, and demos are available on the project page.
